t: Numbers 24
Since*p Balaam saw that it pleased the Lord*s to bless Israel, he did not go to seek omens as on previous occasions, but turned toward the wilderness.
When Balaam looked up and saw Israel encamped tribe by tribe, the Spirit of God came on him,
and he proclaimed his poem: The*pn oracle of Balaam son of Beor, the*ln oracle of the man whose eyes are opened,
the*ln oracle of one who hears the sayings of God, who*ln sees a vision from the Almighty, who*ln falls into a trance with his eyes uncovered:
How*ln beautiful are your tents, Jacob, your*ln dwellings, Israel.
They*ln stretch out like river valleys, like*ln gardens beside a stream, like*ln aloes the Lord*s has planted, like*ln cedars beside the water.
Water*ln will flow from his buckets, and*ln his seed will be by abundant water. His*ln king will be greater than Agag, and*ln his kingdom will be exalted.
God*ln brought him out of Egypt; he*ln is like the horns of a wild ox for them. He*ln will feed on enemy nations and*ln gnaw their bones; he*ln will strike them with his arrows.
He*ln crouches, he lies down like a lion or*ln a lioness - who dares to rouse him? Those*ln who bless you will be blessed, and*ln those who curse you will be cursed.
Then*p Balak became furious with Balaam, struck his hands together, and said to him, “I summoned you to put a curse on my enemies, but instead, you have blessed them these three times.
Now go to your home! I said I would reward you richly, but look, the Lord*s has denied you a reward.”
Balaam*p answered Balak, “Didn’t I previously tell the messengers you sent me:
If Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I could not go against the Lord’s*s command, to do anything good or bad of my own will? I will say whatever the Lord*s says.
Now I am going back to my people, but first, let me warn you what these people will do to your people in the future.”
Balaam’s Fourth Oracle
Then*p he proclaimed his poem: The*pn oracle of Balaam son of Beor, the*ln oracle of the man whose eyes are opened;
the*ln oracle of one who hears the sayings of God and*ln has knowledge from the Most High, who*ln sees a vision from the Almighty, who*ln falls into a trance with his eyes uncovered:

I*ln see him, but not now; I*ln perceive him, but not near. A*ln star will come from Jacob, and*ln a scepter will arise from Israel. He*ln will smash the forehead of Moab and*ln strike down all the Shethites.
Edom*ln will become a possession; Seir*ln will become a possession of its enemies, but*ln Israel will be triumphant.
One*ln who comes from Jacob will rule; he*ln will destroy the city’s survivors.
Then*p Balaam saw Amalek and proclaimed his poem: Amalek*pn was first among the nations, but*ln his future is destruction.
Next*p he saw the Kenites and proclaimed his poem: Your*pn dwelling place is enduring; your*ln nest is set in the cliffs.
Kain*ln will be destroyed when*ln Asshur takes you captive.
Once*p more he proclaimed his poem: Ah,*pn who can live when God does this?
Ships*ln will come from the coast of Kittim; they*ln will carry out raids against Asshur and Eber, but*ln they too will come to destruction.
Balaam*p then arose and went back to his homeland, and Balak also went his way.
